bestBHT.bht: Looking at the evening sky, a man says, Fine weather, and in the morning, Storm today. Christ rebukes their carnal and sensuous expectations, as they were excessively occupied with earthly advantages and cared little about anything heavenly. Recognizing the signs of the sky but failing to recognize the signs of the kingdom of God, they were blind to the manifest signs and miracles confirming Christ's Messiahship. With their misplaced priorities, Christ gives them no other answer than this.

Henry Alford: He sighed deeply in his spirit...
Marvin Vincent: Fair weather [ευδια] . Colloquial. Looking at the evening sky, a may says to his neighbor, "Fine weather :" and in the morning (ver. 3), "Storm today" [σημερον χειμων] .
John Calvin: The comparison which he employs is beautiful and highly appropriate; for, though the aspect of the sky is changeable, so that sometimes a storm unexpectedly arises, and sometimes fair weather springs up when it was not expected, yet the instructions of nature are sufficient to enable men to predict from signs whether the day will be fair or cloudy.
Christ therefore asks why they do not recognize the kingdom of God when it is made known by signs not less manifest...
...they were excessively occupied with earthly and transitory advantages, and cared little about anything that related to the heavenly and spiritual life...
Philip Schaff: In answer to their demand for a ‘sign from heaven,’ our Lord cites two weather ‘signs,’ such as all men look for, ‘in the face of the heaven.’" (Matthew 16:2)
These signs (cited, not given by our Lord) hold good in other regions." (Matthew 16:2)
The design was to rebuke their carnal and sensuous expectations." (Matthew 16:2)
Archibald T. Robertson: Fair weather (ευδια). An old poetic word from ευ and Ζευς as the ruler of the air and giver of fair weather."
So men today say 'when the sky is red at sunset.'
These verses are similar to Luke 12:54-56.
John Gill: Knowing full well their views, and having wrought sufficient miracles to confirm his Messiahship, he thought fit to give them no other answer than this."
When the sun is setting, it is a common thing for you to say, looking up to the heavens, and observing the face and colour of them, that it is like to be fair weather."
which show the clouds to be very thin, and so will soon waste away, and consequently fine weather must follow.

bhtAttempts.bht: Looking at the evening sky, a may says to his neighbor, Fine weather, and in the morning, Storm today. Our Lord cites these weather signs to rebuke their carnal and sensuous expectations, as they were excessively occupied with earthly and transitory advantages and cared little about anything that related to the heavenly and spiritual life. Christ asks why they do not recognize the kingdom of God when it is made known by signs not less manifest, and knowing full well their views and having wrought sufficient miracles to confirm his Messiahship, he thought fit to give them no other answer than this.
